data.title: Emmanuel Macron opens door of his elitist alma mater to the French masses
data.meta_description: The two grandest secondary schools in France are in revolt over a move by President Macron, a former pupil, to force them to take more students who are not fr
data.text:
The two grandest secondary schools in France are in revolt over a move by President Macron, a former pupil, to force them to take more students who are not from affluent families.

The Lycée Louis-le-Grand and the Lycée Henri-IV, ancient institutions in the heart of the Latin Quarter, Paris, have been stripped of the right to select their entrants; a privilege they have held as the “temples of excellence” among elite state sixth-form colleges. Selection will in future be based on an algorithm that was recently applied to public establishments.

Some parents and teachers see the government effort to “desegregate” the schools as a death blow to noble establishments, which have an astonishing roll-call of famous old boys.

Louis-le-Grand, a former Jesuit college founded
